config.question: What did the Supreme Court rule in the Northern Securities case?

choices.content: It ordered the Northern Securities Company to be dissolved because it violated the Sherman Antitrust Act.
It ordered the Northern Securities Company to be dissolved because it violated the Clayton Antitrust Act.
It placed the Northern Securities Company under the supervision of the Bureau of Corporations.
It placed the Northern Securities Company under the supervision of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

answer_3.response: In 1902, Roosevelt instructed the Justice Department to sue the Northern Securities Company for violating the Sherman Antitrust Act. It was a shrewd move. A mammoth holding company, Northern Securities controlled the massive rail networks of the Northern Pacific, Great Northern, and Chicago, Burlington & Quincy railroads. In 1904, the Supreme Court ordered the company dissolved.
